name: Nmap
summary: Nmap (Network Mapper) is a powerful open-source tool for network discovery and security auditing. It discovers hosts, detects services, fingerprints OS metadata, and can execute NSE scripts for deeper checks.

installation_guides.summary: Install from the official repositories and keep scripts up to date.
Kali ships an up-to-date Nmap plus extra NSE scripts.
Run Nmap in a disposable container when you cannot install it locally.

quick_examples.description: Scan specific ports with version detection
Full TCP scan with service detection

operational_tips: Always run scans with permission and document scope clearly.
Use -T4 for faster scans on reliable networks; -T2 when evading detection.
Combine flags: sudo nmap -sS -sV -O -T4 target
Enable verbose output with -v or --reason to inspect why ports are marked open or closed.
Schedule long-running scans during maintenance windows to avoid network noise.

steps.title: ARP sweep local VLAN
steps.details: Use ARP ping to enumerate directly connected hosts before touching routers.

steps.title: ICMP fallback for remote ranges
steps.details: When L2 access is unavailable rely on ICMP echo probes or trusted jump boxes.

steps.title: Persist results for later phases
steps.details: Store responsive hosts in grepable output for targeted service scans.

steps.title: Enumerate top ports with banners
steps.details: Run a fast TCP sweep that captures basic service metadata.

steps.title: Run targeted NSE scripts
steps.details: Only execute scripts that match the validated services to save time.

stages.label: Mass discovery
stages.description: Kick off masscan or naabu to flag responsive ports at high speed.

stages.label: Service validation
stages.description: Feed responsive hosts into Nmap for accurate service/OS fingerprinting.

stages.label: Scripted follow-up
stages.description: Launch NSE scripts only against the services that matter most.

stages.label: Reporting
stages.description: Export grepable output for notebooks and tracking dashboards.

output_notes.meaning: Target responded to discovery probes. Expect accompanying PORT lines soon after.
Header row describing the columns that follow. STATE values of open/closed/filtered map directly to the TCP handshake result.

output_notes.indicator: Warning: OSScan results may be unreliable...
output_notes.meaning: OS detection needs at least one open and one closed port. Provide more targets or explicitly scan additional ports.

advanced_usage.title: Stealthy full TCP fingerprinting
advanced_usage.scenario: Blend service, OS and script data in a single sweep against mid-sized networks.
notes: Tune --scan-delay/--max-rate on fragile networks to avoid tripping IDS baseline checks.

advanced_usage.title: IPv6 neighbor discovery and scan
advanced_usage.scenario: Enumerate dual-stack hosts that may not appear in IPv4 scopes.
notes: Combine with --script ipv6-node-info,targets-ipv6-multicast for richer SLAAC findings.

comparison_table.caption: Choosing the right scanner
rows: Huge address ranges or early sweeps

resources.label: Nmap Reference Guide
resources.description: Official documentation for every option and timing nuance.

resources.label: NSE Script Gallery
resources.description: Searchable catalog of bundled scripts with usage notes.

resources.label: Nmap cheat sheet
resources.description: Community-maintained reminders for offensive and defensive teams.

name: Masscan
summary: Masscan is an Internet-scale port scanner capable of sending millions of packets per second. Use it for rapid discovery before deeper Nmap scans.

installation_guides.summary: Build from source for latest features

steps.detail: sudo apt install -y git gcc make libpcap-dev

quick_examples.description: Scan top 100 ports on a subnet
Full TCP scan of a host
Scan known ports with banner grab

common_flags.description: Bind to a specific source IP/port

operational_tips: Masscan requires root; consider --rate to respect network capacity.
Use results as input to slower but deeper Nmap scans.
Always exclude production ranges if not in scope.
Plan scans during maintenance to avoid IDS alerts.

steps.title: Configure exclusions
steps.details: Create exclude.txt with out-of-scope networks to honor ROE.

steps.title: Launch fast sweep
steps.details: Scan entire ranges at millions of packets/second.

steps.title: Parse results
steps.details: Extract open ports for Nmap follow-up.

workflow_guides.name: High-Speed Port Discovery and Service Validation

stages.label: Masscan sweep
stages.description: Quickly identify live services across huge ranges.

stages.label: Nmap deep scan
stages.description: Validate and fingerprint services on discovered hosts.

output_notes.meaning: Masscan found a responsive port; follow up with Nmap for service details.
Current packet rate; tune with --rate to balance speed vs. network stability.

advanced_usage.title: Banners and application detection
advanced_usage.scenario: Grab banners inline to identify web servers and load balancers.
notes: Combine with --source-ip when scanning through multiple interfaces.

name: Naabu
summary: Naabu is a fast port scanner written in Go that allows you to enumerate valid ports for hosts in a fast and reliable manner.

installation_guides.summary: Install from Go or use pre-built binary

operational_tips: Use JSON output for easy integration with other tools.
Adjust rate to balance speed and stealth.
Combine with Nmap for detailed service detection.
Use CIDR notation for network scanning.

steps.title: Single host scan
steps.details: Enumerate all ports on a target quickly.

steps.title: Subnet scan
steps.details: Scan multiple hosts from file or CIDR.

steps.title: Service integration
steps.details: Pipe results to httpx for web service probing.

workflow_guides.name: Fast Port Scanning with Nuclei Vulnerability Integration

stages.label: Vulnerability scanning
stages.description: Run Nuclei templates against live services.

output_notes.meaning: Open port found; format is host:port for easy piping.

output_notes.indicator: [INF] Running SYN scan with root privileges
output_notes.meaning: Naabu detected sudo/root and switched to faster SYN scanning.

advanced_usage.title: Rate-limited stealth scan
advanced_usage.scenario: Reduce scan rate and increase timeouts to evade IDS/IPS.
notes: Combine with -exclude-ports to skip honeypot services.

name: Nikto
summary: Nikto is a web server scanner that performs comprehensive tests against web servers to find dangerous files/programs and outdated versions.
operational_tips: Use custom user agents to avoid scanner detection.
Save results in HTML format for easy reporting.
Tune scanning options to reduce noise on sensitive targets.
Combine with other web scanners for comprehensive coverage.

steps.title: Basic scan
steps.details: Scan a web server for known issues.

workflow_guides.name: Web Vulnerability Scanning with Nikto and Manual Validation

stages.label: Manual testing
stages.description: Verify findings with Burp Suite or curl.

output_notes.meaning: Nikto found a potentially sensitive directory.
Web server version detected; check for CVEs.

advanced_usage.title: Tuned scan with custom plugins
advanced_usage.scenario: Enable all tuning categories for comprehensive testing.
notes: Use -mutate for username/password guessing against auth endpoints.

name: Dirb
summary: Dirb is a Web Content Scanner that looks for existing (and/or hidden) Web Objects by brute force crawling the web server.
operational_tips: Use comprehensive wordlists for better results.
Combine with multiple file extensions for thorough coverage.
Save results for analysis and later testing.
Consider rate limiting to avoid detection.

workflow_guides.name: Dirb → Content review → Nikto deep scan

output_notes.meaning: Directory found with HTTP 200 response.
Potentially sensitive file discovered.

advanced_usage.title: Recursive scan with extensions
advanced_usage.scenario: Recursively scan found directories and test for specific file extensions.
notes: Use -w to avoid waiting between requests on stable networks.

name: Gobuster
summary: Gobuster is a multithreaded directory, DNS, and virtual host brute-forcing tool. It is perfect for quickly finding hidden web content when you already know the hostname or base URL.

quick_examples.description: Directory scan with extensions and status filters

common_flags.description: Choose directory, DNS, or virtual host mode
Set User-Agent (-a), cookies (-c), or custom header (-H)
Add delay between requests to avoid throttling

operational_tips: Use smaller wordlists first to confirm interesting responses, then scale up.
Leverage PT Journal wordlists in data/wordlists/ or swap in SecLists.
Always review HTTP status codes; -s 200,204,301,302,307,401,403 keeps useful hits.
Add -x php,asp,bak for common backup files.
Combine Gobuster output with proxy logs for deeper insights.

steps.title: Directory brute force
steps.details: Find hidden paths on web server.

output_notes.meaning: Found redirect; follow to discover auth page.
API endpoint discovered; test for documentation or open endpoints.

advanced_usage.title: Multi-extension fuzzing with rate limiting
advanced_usage.command: gobuster dir -u https://example.com -w wordlist.txt -x php,html,txt,bak -t 50 --delay 100ms -o results.txt
advanced_usage.scenario: Test for files with multiple extensions while controlling request rate.
notes: Use -b to exclude specific status codes like 404,403.

name: ffuf
summary: ffuf (Fuzz Faster U Fool) is a blazing fast web fuzzer for discovering files, directories, parameters, and virtual hosts. It supports advanced filters to quickly isolate meaningful responses.

common_flags.description: Filter by match or filter status codes

operational_tips: Mark every location to fuzz with FUZZ (URL paths, headers, POST data).
Use -ic to ignore wordlist comments when using SecLists.
Stack filters (e.g., -mc 200 -fs 0) to hide noise quickly.
Throttle threads (-t) for fragile targets or WAFs.
Store results (-o output.json) for later analysis or reporting.

steps.title: Virtual host fuzzing
steps.details: Find vhosts with Host header manipulation.

stages.label: Filter false positives
stages.description: Exclude by size or word count.

output_notes.meaning: Successful response with content metrics.
Redirect found; potential admin interface.

advanced_usage.title: Multi-stage fuzzing with recursion
advanced_usage.scenario: Automatically fuzz discovered directories with extensions.
notes: Use -rate to limit requests per second for IDS evasion.

name: Wfuzz
summary: Wfuzz is a web application fuzzer used to brute force GET/POST parameters, analyze responses, and find hidden resources.
operational_tips: Use filters (--hc, --hl, --hw) to reduce noise.
Combine multiple wordlists for complex attacks.
Save interesting results for manual testing.
Use POST data for form and API testing.

workflow_guides.name: Web Parameter Fuzzing and SQL Injection Discovery with Wfuzz

stages.label: SQLi probing
stages.description: Test discovered parameters for SQL injection.

output_notes.meaning: Response with HTTP 200, 56 lines, 123 words, 1234 characters.
Potential admin path found; verify manually.

advanced_usage.title: Multi-position fuzzing with filters
advanced_usage.scenario: Simultaneously fuzz multiple positions and filter by status codes.
notes: Use --sc 200 to show only successful responses.

name: Enum4linux
summary: Enum4linux is a tool for enumerating information from Windows and Samba systems, similar to enum.exe but for Linux.
operational_tips: Always try full enumeration first for maximum information.
Use results to identify weak configurations and users.
Document share information for potential access paths.
Combine with SMB exploitation tools for follow-up testing.

workflow_guides.name: SMB Enumeration and Credential Harvesting Pipeline

output_notes.meaning: Target is part of a workgroup, not a domain.
User account discovered with RID.

advanced_usage.title: Authenticated enumeration
advanced_usage.scenario: Use known credentials for deeper enumeration.
notes: Combine with enum4linux-ng for improved parsing and JSON output.

name: SMBMap
summary: SMBMap allows users to enumerate samba share drives across an entire domain. Useful for identifying sensitive shares.
operational_tips: Try null session authentication for anonymous access.
Look for sensitive files in readable shares.
Document permissions for potential privilege escalation.
Be careful with file operations to avoid detection.

steps.title: Authenticated enumeration
steps.details: Use credentials to list shares and permissions.

steps.title: Recursive file listing
steps.details: List all files in accessible shares.

workflow_guides.name: SMBMap → Download sensitive files → Credential extraction

output_notes.meaning: SMBMap is testing SMB connectivity.
Share with read/write access found.

advanced_usage.title: Command execution via SMB
advanced_usage.scenario: Execute remote commands on Windows host via SMB.
notes: Use -L to list drives, -r to browse specific shares.

name: SNMPwalk
summary: SNMPwalk is an SNMP application that uses SNMP GETNEXT requests to query a network entity for a tree of information.
operational_tips: Try common community strings like 'public', 'private', 'cisco'.
Use version 1 for older devices, 2c for modern ones.
Save output for analysis of device configuration.
Combine with SNMP brute force tools for discovery.

steps.title: Basic walk
steps.details: Query all SNMP data with default community string.

stages.label: Full SNMP walk
stages.description: Extract all SNMP data with discovered strings.

output_notes.meaning: System description reveals device type and OS.
Network interface enumeration.

advanced_usage.title: SNMPv3 with authentication
advanced_usage.command: snmpwalk -v3 -u admin -l authPriv -a SHA -A authpass -x AES -X privpass 192.168.1.1
advanced_usage.scenario: Query SNMP with v3 authentication and encryption.
notes: Use snmp-check for automated parsing and reporting.

name: Onesixtyone
summary: Onesixtyone is an SNMP scanner that sends SNMP requests to multiple IP addresses, trying different community strings.
operational_tips: Use comprehensive community string wordlists.
Scan in batches to avoid overwhelming networks.
Save results for follow-up SNMP enumeration.
Combine with detailed SNMPwalk on discovered devices.

stages.label: Extract credentials
stages.description: Find cleartext passwords in SNMP data.

output_notes.meaning: Valid community string found with system info.
Onesixtyone is testing community strings across range.

advanced_usage.title: Fast sweep with custom wordlist
advanced_usage.scenario: Increase wait time for slower networks or devices.
notes: Combine with Nmap SNMP scripts for comprehensive enumeration.
